data.name: Select The Wanted Products
data.description:
See the following list(array):
```
lst = [3, -2, 2, 4, 5]
```
Think in all the products that you may form with the numbers of the above list. This will be the result:
```
[-240, -120, -80, -60, -48, -40, -30, -24, -20, -16, -12, -10, -8, -6, -4, -2, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, 15, 20, 24, 30, 40, 60, 120]
```
Once we have the result, we are interested in all the values that are higher or equal than 10.

So the final result is :

**[10, 12, 15, 20, 24, 30, 40, 60, 120]**

Make the function ```prod_maker()```, that receives a list(or array) and a constraint, or constraints, as a lambda function and ouputs a sorted list with the values of all the possible products that you can form with the elements of the given list.

Let's see some cases:
```python
lst = [3, -2, 2, 4, 5]
f = lambda x: x >= 10
prod_maker(lst, f) == [10, 12, 15, 20, 24, 30, 40, 60, 120]

lst = [3, -2, 2, 4, 5, 1]
f = lambda x: - 20 < x < 80
prod_maker(lst, f) == [-16, -12, -10, -8, -6, -4, -2, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, 15, 20, 24, 30, 40, 60]
```

Your code should handle float numbers in the array making the substitution by the closest integer.

Let's see a case  with the given list having some float numbers:
```python
lst = [3, -2, 2, 4, 5, 0.84, 2.07] # it will be transformed to [3, -2, 2, 4, 5, 1, 2]
f = lambda x: abs(x) > 35
prod_maker(lst, f) == [-480, -240, -160, -120, -96, -80, -60, -48, -40, 40, 48, 60, 80, 120, 240]

lst =             [3, -2, sqrt(2), log(20, e), tan(45* pi/180.0), cos(pi), sin(pi/2.0)]
# transformed to  [3, -2,   1,         3,             1,            -1,        1      ]
f = lambda x: 10 <= abs(x) < 60 and x % 2 == 0
prod_maker(lst, f) == [-18, 18]
```
Observing carefully these examples you will have all the needed functions, and specials numbers that have to be imported from the math library.

Finally, all the strings and undefined values, if they are present in the given list, should be discarded.
```python
lst =             ['', -1, pi, e, None, 'product', 0, log(60, 10)]
# transformed to  [    -1, 3,  3           ,       0,       2      ]
f = lambda x: x > 0 and x % 3 == 0
prod_maker(lst, f) == [3, 6, 9, 18]
```
Enjoy it!!
